questions.text: All of the following are the usual routes of spread of middle ear infections except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lymphatic spread

 

Explanation:

Lymphatic spread is not the usual route of spread of middle ear infections to the adjacent structures, leading to various intracranial and extracranial complications.

 

Routes of the spread of middle ear infections include:

 

Direct Bone Erosion(Option A)

  • Acute Infections: Characterized by hyperaemic decalcification.
  • Chronic Infections:
    • Osteitis
    • Erosion by cholesteatoma or granulation tissue

Venous Thrombophlebitis (Option D)

  • Connection: Veins in Haversian canals of bone are linked with:
    • Dural veins
    • Dural venous sinuses
    • Superficial veins of the brain
  • Infection Spread:
    • Infection from the mastoid bone can lead to:
      • Thrombophlebitis of venous sinuses
      • Cortical vein thrombosis
      • Encephalitis
  • Common in Acute Infections

Pre-formed Pathways (Option C)

  • Congenital Dehiscences:
    • Bony facial canal
    • Floor of middle ear over the jugular bulb
  • Patent Sutures:
    • Petrosquamous suture
  • Previous Skull Fractures:
    • Heal with fibrous scar, permitting infection
  • Surgical Defects:
    • Stapedectomy
    • Fenestration
    • Mastoidectomy with exposure of dura
  • Oval and Round Windows
  • Infection Spread from Labyrinth
    • Travels along:
      • Internal acoustic meatus
      • Aqueducts of the vestibule
      • Aqueducts of the cochlea
      • Meninges

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a severe headache and fever. The patient has a history of chronic otitis media. The CT scan is shown below. Which of the following statements best describes the most common complication in this patient?

choices.text: Localized pus collection within the brain parenchyma.
Pus accumulation between the skull and dura mater.
Blood clot formation in the sigmoid sinus.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Localized pus collection within the brain parenchyma.

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with severe headache and fever, along with a history of chronic otitis media and the CT finding (ring-enhancing lesion), is suggestive of an intracerebral abscess.
  • This is the most common serious complication associated with chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), where the infection spreads to the brain, forming a localized pus collection.
  • Temporal and cerebellar abscesses can arise from the direct spread of infection from the middle ear to the mastoid air cells, extending to the temporal lobe or cerebellum. Additionally, infection may spread directly from the petrous apex to these brain regions.

                                                  Fig: Intracerebral abcess

Meningitis (Option B)

  • Cause: Pus erodes the tegmen (part of the temporal bone) and causes inflammation of the meninges.

Extradural Abscess (Option C)

  • Location: Pus between the bone and the dura mater.

Subdural Abscess

  • Location: Pus between the dura mater and the brain parenchyma.

Brain Abscess

  • Location: Abscess within the brain parenchyma. (Option C)

Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis (Option D)

  • Pathway: Infection or inflammation spreads from the middle ear to the mastoid.
  • Process: Initial inflammation of the sinus wall (periphlebitis), followed by inflammation of the endothelium (endophlebitis), leading to platelet aggregation and thrombus formation in the sigmoid sinus.

Otitic Hydrocephalus

Cause: Dilatation of the brain's ventricles due to ear pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common extracranial complication of Acute Otitis Media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mastoiditis

 

Explanation:

Mastoiditis is the most common extracranial complication of Acute Otitis Media (AOM) because the infection can spread from the middle ear to the mastoid bone, leading to inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells. This condition often requires prompt treatment to prevent further complications. Symptoms include swelling behind the ear, fever, and ear pain.

 

Extracranial complications

  • Acute Mastoiditis: Disease progresses from the middle ear to the mastoid bone via the aditus.
  • Labyrinthitis: Disease progresses from the middle ear to the inner ear.
  • Facial Nerve Palsy: Disease progresses to the internal auditory meatus or along the course of the facial nerve, leading to facial nerve palsy.
  • Petrositis: Infection progresses towards the apex of the petrous bone, causing petrositis.
  • Osteomyelitis: Involves the squamous portion of the temporal bone.
  • Septicemia: Infection spreads to the bloodstream, resulting in septicemia.

Labyrinthitis, facial nerve palsy, and septicemia are less common complications of AOM compared to mastoiditis (Options A, B & D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acute mastoiditis is false?

choices.text: Sagging of the posterosuperior meatal wall.
Pinna usually pushed backwards and upwards.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pinna usually pushed backwards and upwards.

 

Explanation:

Acute Mastoiditis:

  • Definition: Inflammation of the mucosal lining of the mastoid air cells due to infection spreading from acute otitis media, involving the bony walls of the mastoid air-cell system.

Aetiology

  • Primary Cause: Follows or accompanies acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Determining Factors: High virulence of organisms or lowered patient resistance (e.g., measles, exanthematous fevers, poor nutrition, systemic diseases like diabetes).
  • Common Organisms: Beta-haemolytic streptococcus is most common.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Persistent or worsening pain behind the ear.
    • Persistent or recurrent fever despite antibiotics (Option A).
    • Increased, profuse, or obstructed ear discharge.
  • Signs:
    • Ironed Out Appearance of the Mastoid:
      • First sign of acute mastoiditis:Due to inflammation of the mastoid periosteum.
    • Mastoid tenderness.
    • Mucopurulent or purulent ear discharge.
    • Sagging of posterosuperior meatal wall (Option C).
    • Tympanic membrane perforation or dullness.
    • Swelling over the mastoid (Option B).
      • Pushes the pinna forward and downwards.
      • Deepening of the retroauricular sulcus.
    • Conductive hearing loss.
    • Ill appearance with fever, especially in children.
    • Light House Sign:
      • Discharge reflects light and is pulsatile on otoscopy.
    • Positive Reservoir Sign:
      • Immediate Reappearance of Pus After Mopping.

Fig: Mastoiditis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with persistent fever, severe ear pain, and swelling behind the ear, despite antibiotic treatment for acute otitis media. Physical examination reveals significant mastoid tenderness. What would you expect to see on the CT scan, and what is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cavity formation; Antibiotics.

 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with acute mastoiditis, where the CT scan would typically show cavity formation due to pus accumulation in the mastoid air cells. The most appropriate treatment involves starting broad-spectrum antibiotics to manage the infection and performing a myringotomy to relieve pressure.


 

Acute mastoiditis

Investigations

  • Blood Counts: Polymorphonuclear leucocytosis.
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate: Elevated.
  • CT Scan: Clouding of air cells, indistinct bony partitions, potential cavity formation (Options A, B & C)
  • Ear Swab: Culture and sensitivity for aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

Treatment

  1. Hospitalization: Required for management.
  2. Antibiotics: Start with amoxicillin or ampicillin; adjust based on sensitivity report. Include metronidazole if anaerobes are present.
  3. Myringotomy: To relieve pus under tension; often combined with antibiotic treatment.
  4. Treatment of Choice: Cortical Mastoidectomy (Schwartz Operation)
    • Also known as Intact Canal Wall Mastoidectomy
    • Procedure:
      1. Remove all mastoid air cells
      2. Create a single cavity
    • Landmarks:
      1. Tegmen
      2. Sigmoid sinus
      3. Tip of the mastoid
      4. Bulge of the lateral semicircular canal

All these landmarks should be visible if the patient has undergone cortical mastoidectomy

 

 

First figure depicts left temporal bone showing cortical mastoidectomy showing facial nerve (white arrow) in the deepest part of the posterior canal wall.

Second figure is an illustrative picture showing structures in dissected temporal bone (yellow line: facial nerve, blue line: sigmoid sinus bulge and pink dotted line: dural or tegmen plate).

(DR: Digastric ridge; EAC: External auditory canal; PCW: Posterior canal wall; LSCC: Lateral semicircular canal; PSCC: Posterior semicircular canal; SSCC: Superior semicircular canal)

 

  • Posterior Wall of External Auditory Canal:
    1. Left intact
  • Indicated in cases of:
    1. Subperiosteal abscess.
    2. Sagging of the posterosuperior meatal wall.
    3. Positive reservoir sign.
    4. Persistent or worsening condition despite treatment.
    5. Complications such as facial paralysis or intracranial issues.
    6. Post-Operative Care: Continue antibiotics for at least 7 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic triad of symptoms associated with Gradenigo Syndrome?

choices.text: Fever, facial swelling, and hearing loss
External rectus palsy, retro-orbital pain, and Ear discharge

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External rectus palsy, retro-orbital pain, and Ear discharge

Explanation:

Gradenigo Syndrome is characterized by a triad of symptoms due to petrous apicitis: external rectus palsy (which causes eye movement difficulties), retro-orbital pain (deep pain behind the eye), and persistent ear discharge. These symptoms result from the spread of infection from the middle ear to the petrous apex of the temporal bone.

 

Petrositis (Petrous Apicitis)

Definition:

  • Infection spreading from the middle ear and mastoid to the petrous part of the temporal bone is known as petrositis.

Clinical Features:

  • Gradenigo Syndrome - Classic triad:
    • External rectus palsy (VIth nerve palsy).
    • Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain (Vth nerve involvement).
    • Persistent ear discharge.
  • Additional Symptoms:
    • Persistent ear discharge despite mastoidectomy.
    • Fever, headache, vomiting, neck rigidity.
    • Facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo may occur.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging:
    • CT Scan: Shows bony details and air cells.
    • MRI: Differentiates between diploic marrow and fluid/pus.

Treatment:

  • Surgical Intervention:
    • Mastoidectomy: Cortical, modified radical, or radical, depending on the extent.
    • Fistulous Tract Management: Curettage and enlargement for drainage.
    • Approach:
      • Posterosuperior Cells: Found in Trautmann’s triangle or attic.
      • Anterior Cells: Near the eustachian tube, above the carotid artery, anterior to the cochlea; may require radical mastoidectomy.
      • Transcochlear/ Translabyrinthine Approach: If hearing loss is complete.

          ​​​​​​​                                  Fig: Trautmann’s triangle

  • Antibacterial Therapy:
    • High doses initially, continued for 4-5 days post-symptom resolution.
    • Often sufficient for acute cases without surgery.

Fever, facial swelling, and hearing loss (Option A): These signs are not specific to Gradenigo Syndrome.

Nausea, vertigo, and tinnitus (Option C): These signs are typical of vestibular disorders

Headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia (Option D): They are rather the signs of meningitis

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient has intermittent vertigo, particularly triggered while cleaning his ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a tympanic membrane perforation. A fistula test is positive, and imaging confirms localized erosion of the horizontal semicircular canal. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CSOM with cholesteatoma

 

Explanation:

Circumscribed Labyrinthitis is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario. The most common cause is chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma which leads to thinning or erosion of the bony capsule of the labyrinth, usually of the horizontal semicircular canal.

 

Labyrinthitis:

  • Inflammation of the labyrinth
  • It is of three types:

 

 

Circumscribed

Diffuse serous

Diffuse suppurative

Pathology
  • Thinning or erosion of the bony capsule of the labyrinth
  • Most commonly horizontal semicircular canal is involved
  • Diffuse intralabyrinthine inflammation without pus formation
  • It is reversible
  • Diffuse pyogenic infection of the labyrinth.
  • Permanent loss of vestibular and cochlear functions

Etiology
  • Most common: Chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma (Option A)
  • Neoplasms of the middle ear like carcinoma or glomus tumour (Option D ruled out)
  • Surgical or accidental trauma
  • Most common: progression of preexisting circumscribed labyrinthitis associated with chronic middle ear suppuration or cholesteatoma.
  • Acute otitis media (Option B ruled out)
  • Following a stapedectomy or fenestration operation

Progression of serous labyrinthitis associated with pyogenic organisms (Option C ruled out)

Clinical manifestations
  • Transient nystagmus and vertigo induced by pressure on the tragus, cleaning the ear, or Valsalva maneuver
  • Fistula sign is positive

Vertigo (single long episode) with sensorineural hearing loss.

 
  • Severe vertigo with nausea and vomiting
  • Total sensorineural hearing loss

Nystagmus
  • Positive pressure- nystagmus to the same side
  • Negative pressure- nystagmus to the opposite side
  • Nystagmus to the affected side

Nystagmus to the opposite side

Treatment

Management of the cause
  • Antibacterial therapy
  • Labyrinthine sedatives
  • Surgery: Cortical mastoidectomy or modified radical mastoidectomy
  • It is the same as diffuse serous labyrinthitis
  • Drainage of the labyrinth to evacuate the pus

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is admitted with high fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. The child was recently treated for acute otitis media. Lumbar puncture shows a predominance of polymorphs, protein level is raised, sugars reduced and chlorides diminished. Otoscopic examination reveals bulging of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention to manage the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myringotomy

 

Explanation:

The child is most probably suffering from bacterial meningitis secondary to acute otitis media in this case. Myringotomy is indicated here to relieve pressure (bulging tympanic membrane), drain the middle ear infection, and prevent further spread of infection into the intracranial space.

 

Meningitis:

  • Most common intracranial complication of otitis media
  • In infants and children, otogenic meningitis usually follows acute otitis media
  • In adults, it is due to chronic middle ear infection

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • High-grade fever with chills and rigors.
  • Projectile vomiting
  • Headache
  • Altered sensorium
  • Drowsiness and irritability
  • Photophobia
  • Brudzinski's sign: Flexion of neck results in flexion of hip and knee
  • Kernig's sign: With the thighs flexed on the abdomen there is pain while trying to extend it

 

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis with culture and sensitivity- helps in deciding on the antibiotic therapy (Option D)
  • CT or MRI with contrast

 

Treatment:

  • Antibiotics
  • Corticosteroids
  • If the source of infection is:
    • Acute otitis media- myringotomy or cortical mastoidectomy (Option A)

Chronic otitis media with cholesteatoma- radical or modified radical mastoidectomy (Options B & C)

questions.text: A 42-year-old right-handed patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media presents with headache, fever, and left-sided weakness. On examination, nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, and reduced power in his left limbs are noted. CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely route of infection spread in this patient?

choices.text: Direct extension from the mastoid cavity
Retrograde spread through the lymphatic system
Both A and B are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Both A and B are correct

 

Explanation:

  • CT brain shows a discrete lesion with a thin rim-enhancing lesion.
  • The patient is most likely suffering from a temporal lobe abscess based on the clinical history of CSOM, symptoms, and signs.
  • In patients with CSOM, it develops due to direct extension from the middle ear through the tegmen or by retrograde thrombophlebitis.

 

Otogenic brain abscess:

  • It is the most common intracranial complication of CSOM.
  • 50% of brain abscesses in adults are otogenic in origin.
  • Organism: Both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Routes of spread: (Option D)

  • Direct extension of middle ear infection through the tegmen.
  • Retrograde thrombophlebitis.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Raised intracranial pressure,
    • Headache, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, stupor.
    • Papilledema and bradycardia.
  • Temporal lobe abscess- epilepsy, nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, contralateral motor paralysis.
  • Cerebellar abscess- suboccipital headache, spontaneous nystagmus, ipsilateral weakness and ataxia, dysmetria, and dysdiadochokinesia.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Contrast-Enhanced CT/ MRI with contrast: Rim-enhancing lesion with surrounding brain parenchyma edema.
  • Lumbar puncture: Raised pressure, increase in protein, and white cell count, normal glucose level.

 

Treatment:

  • Medical: IV antibiotics, dexamethasone, and mannitol to stabilize the patient.
  • Surgical:
    • Drainage of brain abscess.
    • Otologic- Modified radical mastectomy for CSOM/Cholesteatoma.


Retrograde spread through the lymphatic system (Option C): There is no known evidence for the spread of infection from the ear or mastoid air cells to the brain to form an abscess. Retrograde lymphatic spread of cancer cells occurs against the direction of lymphatic flow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic otitis media, presents with severe headache, fever, and confusion. Fundoscopy reveals papilledema. Collection of pus between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater is visualized on MRI brain. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subdural abscess

 

Explanation:

A subdural abscess is a collection of pus between dura and arachnoid (subdural space). It presents with fever, headache, and vomiting with localizing neurological signs. Pus collection is visualized on an MRI brain.


 

 

Extradural abscess

Subdural abscess

Pathology

Collection of pus between the bone and dura. (Option A)

Collection of pus between dura and arachnoid. (Option B)

Clinical manifestations
  • Most of the time it is asymptomatic, SILENT abscess.
  • Persistent headache on the side of otitis media
  • Severe ear pain
  • Pulsatile purulent ear discharge
  • Disappearance of headache with free flow of pus from the ear (spontaneous abscess drainage)
  • Meningeal irritation
  • Cortical Venous Thrombophlebitis
  • Raised Intracranial Tension
  • Focal neurological deficits

Diagnosis

CT/MRI

CT/MRI

Treatment
  • Mastoidectomy for clearance of the disease
  • IV antibiotics
  • Drainage of pus
  • Burr holes or a craniotomy to drain subdural empyema
  • IV antibiotics
  • Later, mastoidectomy for clearance of disease

 

Cerebral abscess (Option C): Also known as brain abscess is an abscess located in the cerebrum parenchyma.


Epidural abscess (Option C): Epidural and extradural space refers to the same space between the dura mater and the bones of the skull or vertebral column. The terms extradural and epidural are commonly used when referring to the brain and spinal cord respectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media complaints of fever with chills and rigors, ear pain, and headache. On examination, he has mastoid tenderness. Fundoscopy reveals papilledema and engorgement of retinal veins when the jugular vein is compressed. A CT scan is done and shown below. Which of the following radiological findings is most consistent with lateral/sigmoid sinus thrombophlebitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delta sign

 

Explanation:

The "Delta sign" is the radiological finding on contrast-enhanced CT or MR venography, indicating a filling defect due to thrombus within the sinus.

Delta or empty triangle sign

Lateral/sigmoid sinus thrombophlebitis

Inflammation of the inner wall of lateral venous sinus with formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

 

Etiology

  • Acute coalescent mastoiditis
  • Chronic suppuration of middle ear
  • Cholesteatoma

 

Pathophysiology:

Clinical manifestation:

  • Hectic picket fence type of fever with chills and rigors (picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity)
  • Headache
  • Griesinger Sign: Oedema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein (Option A ruled out)
  • Papilloedema with retinal hemorrhages or dilated veins
  • Tobey-Ayer Test: Compression of the jugular vein on the normal side causes a rise in the CSF pressure
  • Crowe-Beck Test: Engorgement of retinal veins and supraorbital veins when the jugular vein on the normal side is compressed
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein

 

Diagnosis:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT: Triangular filling defect area with rim enhancement and central low-density (Delta sign) (Option B)
  • Others: Contrast-enhanced MRI, MR venography

Ring enhancement (Option C): Contrast-enhanced CT/ MRI with contrast shows a rim-enhancing lesion with surrounding brain parenchyma edema in brain abscess.

 

Crescent sign (Option D): In subdural hemorrhage, a CT scan is characterized by a crescent-shaped hyperdense collection along the convexity of the brain, indicating blood accumulation between the dura and the arachnoid mater.

questions.text: A patient with otitic hydrocephalus develops headaches, visual disturbances, and papilledema but no focal neurological deficits. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on lumbar puncture?

choices.text: Normal CSF composition with elevated opening pressure
High neutrophil count in the CSF
Decreased glucose and elevated protein in the CSF
Low opening pressure and elevated protein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Normal CSF composition with elevated opening pressure

 

Explanation: In otitic hydrocephalus, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) typically remains normal in composition and bacteriologically sterile, but there is an elevated opening pressure when performing a lumbar puncture due to raised intracranial pressure.

 

Otitic hydrocephalus:

Pathophysiology:

Formation of lateral sinus thrombosis due to middle ear infection obstructs the venous return causing raised intracranial tension.

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Severe headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Diplopia due to paralysis of the VIth cranial nerve
  • Papilloedema
  • Nystagmus due to raised intracranial tension

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture:
    • Raised CSP pressure
    • Normal in cell, protein, and sugar content and bacteriologically sterile
  • CT scan- dilatation of ventricles

 

Treatment:

  • Acetazolamide
  • Corticosteroids
  • Frequent lumbar puncture or lumbar drain placement
  • Lumboperitoneal shunting
  • Middle ear infection: Antibiotics and mastoid exploration
